an7.66.blurb: A rare discourse on cosmic evolution. The Buddha describes the successive appearance of seven suns and how even the earth will be burned up.

an7.55.blurb: Seven kinds of rebirth for non-returners, as well as extinguishment by not grasping.

an7.69.blurb: The blossoming of the Shady Orchid Tree delights the gods of the Thirty-Three, and in the same way, the renunciation of a Buddhist ascetic is delightful.

an7.26.blurb: The Buddha teaches seven principles of non-decline to the mendicants.

an7.91.blurb: A noble one destroys seven defilements.

an7.58.blurb: Four areas where the Realized One has nothing to hide, and three ways he is irreproachable.

an7.21.blurb: The Buddha teaches the seven principles of non-decline to the Licchavis at the Sārandada shrine near Vesālī.

an7.84.blurb: Seven principles for settling issues and disputes that have arisen in the community.

an7.77.translated_title: An Expert in the Monastic Law (3rd)
an7.77.blurb: An expert in monastic conduct has seven qualities.

an7.39.blurb: With seven qualities, Sāriputta realized the four kinds of textual analysis.

an7.617.blurb: Develop insight into greed through seven perceptions starting with ugliness.

an7-abyakatavagga.translated_title: The Chapter on the Undeclared Points

an7.20.blurb: A mendicant with seven qualities is qualified to graduate.

an7.12.blurb: The purpose of the spiritual life is to give up the underlying tendencies of sensual desire, repulsion, views, doubt, conceit, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.

an7.32.blurb: A god speaks of the the seven principles of non-decline to the Buddha, who repeats it to the mendicants.

an7.42.blurb: Sāriputta visits a sectarian hermitage and hears them saying that someone who lives the spiritual life for twelve years is fit to graduate. The Buddha rejects this, saying that a mendicant is qualified to graduate not merely by completing a certain number of years, but because of their spiritual qualities.

an7.70.blurb: Sāriputta reflects on what a mendicant should revere in order to develop the wholesome. He reports to the Buddha that these things are indeed found in himself.

an7.38.blurb: With seven qualities, a mendicant will soon realize the four kinds of textual analysis.

an7.14.blurb: Seven persons who are worthy of gifts and veneration.

an7.37.blurb: When a mendicant has seven factors, one should stay close to them even if they send you away.

an7.31.blurb: Seven ruins for a lay follower.

an7.40.blurb: Seven qualities leading to mastery of meditation.

an7.9.blurb: The purpose of the spiritual life is to give up the fetters of compliance, repulsion, views, doubt, conceit, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.

an7.50.blurb: The brahmin Jāṇussoṇī asks the Buddha about behaviors that are a blemish to the celibate life.

an7.29.blurb: Seven qualities leading to the decline of a lay follower.

an7.95.blurb: Seven people worthy of offerings due to observing impermanence in the eye.

an7.24.blurb: The Buddha teaches seven principles of non-decline to the mendicants.

an7-vinayavagga.translated_title: The Chapter on the Monastic Law

an7.22.blurb: King Ajātasattu of Magadha wishes to invade the Vajjians, and sends his minister Vassakāra to tell the Buddha of his intentions. The Buddha recalls the time he taught the seven principles of non-decline to the Vajjians.

an7.6.blurb: The wealth of faith, energy, conscience, prudence, learning, generosity, and wisdom.

an7.54.blurb: The Buddha explains why a noble disciple has no doubt when it comes to the unexplained points.

an7.56.blurb: Two gods come to the Buddha on Vulture’s Peak and declare that the nuns are liberated. Moggallāna interrogates one of the deities on what he means, and the Buddha adds further explanation.

an7.73.blurb: There have been many great teachers in the past, who should not be reviled. But reviling a single noble disciple is even more serious.

an7.82.translated_title: Shines as an Expert in the Monastic Law (4th)
an7.82.blurb: An expert in monastic conduct shines with seven qualities.

an7.57.blurb: The Buddha explains the benefits of giving that are visible in the present life, and one that is only apparent in the next.

an7.71.blurb: Liberation doesn’t happen because you wish for it, but because you develop the path.

an7.618-644.blurb: Develop complete understanding, etc., of greed.

an7.53.blurb: Sāriputta and Moggallāna are on tour in the southern hills. A deity informs the laywoman Veḷukaṇṭakī that they are approaching. When Sāriputta expresses his amazement that she speaks with the gods, she goes on to list many other of her own amazing qualities.

an7.46.blurb: Seven fires, some physical, some psychological.

an7.16.blurb: Seven persons who are worthy of gifts and veneration.

an7.34.blurb: The Buddha tells of hearing the seven principles of non-decline from a god.

an7.47.blurb: The brahmin Uggatasarīra has arranged a great sacrifice. On Ānanda’s advice, he asks the Buddha how to make a sacrifice beneficial.

an7.76.translated_title: An Expert in the Monastic Law (2nd)
an7.76.blurb: An expert in monastic conduct has seven qualities.

an7.3.blurb: The powers of faith, energy, conscience, prudence, mindfulness, samādhi, and wisdom.

an7.11.blurb: The underlying tendencies of sensual desire, repulsion, views, doubt, conceit, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.

an7.49.blurb: Meditating on seven perceptions leads to the deathless, in detail.

an7.90.blurb: A knowledge master destroys seven defilements.

an7.8.blurb: The fetters of compliance, repulsion, views, doubt, conceit, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.

an7.43.blurb: Ānanda visits a sectarian hermitage and hears them saying that someone who lives the spiritual life for twelve years is fit to graduate. The Buddha rejects this, saying that a mendicant is qualified to graduate not merely by completing a certain number of years, but because of their spiritual qualities.

an7.45.blurb: The path factors are the prerequisite for right immersion.

an7.78.translated_title: An Expert in the Monastic Law (4th)
an7.78.blurb: An expert in monastic conduct has seven qualities.

an7.83.blurb: The Buddha teaches the Vinaya expert Upāli a short summary of the teaching.

an7.44.blurb: Seven planes of consciousness in which beings may be reborn.

an7.1.blurb: Seven qualities that make a mendicant either agreeable or disagreeable to their fellow monastics.

an7.18.blurb: Seven persons who are worthy of gifts and veneration.

an7.7.blurb: Migāra of Rohaṇa is a wealthy man, but even his riches are vulnerable to the vicissitudes of life, unlike spiritual wealth.

an7.52.blurb: The lay followers of Campā seek a teaching from the Buddha. Together with Sāriputta, they ask the Buddha about what makes a gift fruitful.

an7.645-1124.blurb: Develop complete understanding, etc., of hate, etc.

an7.92.blurb: A perfected one destroys seven defilements.

an7.19.blurb: Seven persons who are worthy of gifts and veneration.

an7.68.blurb: A mendicant who has seven qualities is worthy, with a special emphasis on listening to and learning the teaching.

an7.96-614.translated_title: Observing Suffering in the Eye, Etc.
an7.96-614.blurb: Seven people worthy of offerings due to observing suffering, etc., in the eye, etc.

an7.72.translated_title: The Simile of the Great Mass of Fire
an7.72.blurb: It would be better for a monk to embrace a blazing fire than to lie with a maiden.

an7.79.translated_title: Shines as an Expert in the Monastic Law (1st)
an7.79.blurb: An expert in monastic conduct shines with seven qualities.

an7.89.blurb: A bathed initiate destroys seven defilements.

an7.74.blurb: Araka was a famous teacher long ago, when the life span was much greater than today. Nevertheless, he still taught impermanence; how much more is it relevant today!

an7.48.blurb: Meditating on seven perceptions leads to the deathless, in brief.

an7.33.blurb: The Buddha tells of hearing the seven principles of non-decline from a god.

an7.35.blurb: The Buddha tells of hearing the seven principles of non-decline from a god. Sāriputta offers additional explanation.

an7.2.blurb: Seven qualities that make a mendicant either agreeable or disagreeable to their fellow monastics.

an7.59.blurb: Venerable Kimbila asks the Buddha the reasons for the long-lasting of Buddhism after the Buddha’s demise.

an7.80.translated_title: Shines as an Expert in the Monastic Law (2nd)
an7.80.blurb: An expert in monastic conduct shines with seven qualities.

an7-mahayannavagga.translated_title: The Chapter on a Great Sacrifice

an7.30.blurb: Seven failures for a lay follower.

an7.75.translated_title: An Expert in the Monastic Law (1st)
an7.75.blurb: An expert in monastic conduct has seven qualities.

an7.93.blurb: Seven bad qualities starting with faithlessness.

an7-vajjisattakavagga.translated_title: The Chapter on the Vajji Seven

an7.4.blurb: The powers of faith, energy, conscience, prudence, mindfulness, samādhi, and wisdom.

an7.61.blurb: Before his awakening, Moggallāna is struggling with sleepiness in meditation. The Buddha visits him and gives seven ways to dispel drowsiness, and other important teachings.

an7.27.blurb: The Buddha teaches seven principles of non-decline to the mendicants.

an7.94.blurb: Seven good qualities starting with faith.

an7.28.blurb: Seven qualities leading to the decline of a mendicant who is a trainee.

an7.616.blurb: Develop insight into greed through seven perceptions starting with impermanence.

an7.64.blurb: When someone is angry, they wish ill upon their enemy, and are disappointed if they do well. This sutta includes a powerful set of verses.

an7.13.blurb: Factors that make a family worth visiting.

an7.15.blurb: Seven people found in the world who are like those in water.

an7.67.blurb: When a king’s fortress is well supplied with seven things and has four kinds of food supplies it is impregnable. Similarly, a noble disciple with seven qualities and the four absorptions is impregnable.

an7.10.blurb: The fetters of compliance, repulsion, views, doubt, conceit, envy, and stinginess.

an7.17.blurb: Seven persons who are worthy of gifts and veneration.

an7.51.blurb: By focusing on their own gendered attributes, a man or woman becomes attached to them and develops lust for the opposite sex.

an7.62.blurb: The incalculable benefits of merit that last for many aeons.

an7.615.blurb: Develop insight into greed through the awakening factors.

an7.81.translated_title: Shines as an Expert in the Monastic Law (3rd)
an7.81.blurb: An expert in monastic conduct shines with seven qualities.

an7.41.blurb: With seven qualities, Sāriputta became a master of meditation.

an7.63.blurb: Anāthapiṇḍika’s home was in an uproar due to the badly behaved Sujātā, newly wedded to one of his sons. The Buddha speaks to her on the different kinds of wives.

an7.36.blurb: When a friend has seven factors, one should associate with them.

an7.5.blurb: The wealth of faith, energy, conscience, prudence, learning, generosity, and wisdom.

an7.65.blurb: A sense of conscience is the foundation that leads step by step to liberation.

an7.25.blurb: The Buddha teaches seven principles of non-decline to the mendicants.

an7.23.blurb: The Buddha teaches the seven principles of non-decline to the mendicants.

an8.1.blurb: The eight benefits of practicing the meditation on love.

an.blurb: The “Numbered” or “Numerical” Discourses are usually known as Aṅguttara Nikāya in Pali, abbreviated AN. However, the Pali tradition also knows the form Ekottara (“one-up” or “incremental”), and this is the form usually found in the northern collections. These collections organize texts in numbered sets, from one to eleven. Compared to the other nikāyas, they are more oriented to the lay community. The Ekottarikāgama (EA) in Chinese is a highly unusual text, which features a range of variations within itself when it comes even to basic doctrines. It shares considerably less in common with the Pali Aṅguttara than the other collections do with their counterparts. In addition, there is a partial Ekottarikāgama in Chinese, as well as a variety of individual discourses and fragments in Chinese and Sanskrit.
